I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.      The proposed technical assistance (TA)1 is included in the aide memoire of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) country programming midterm review mission 2010. The proposed TA 
is aligned with the 2009 Energy Policy of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in the greater use 
of renewable energy, and also addresses the key pillars of the country partnership strategy 
(2008–2010). The proposed TA aims at enhancing the capacity of large-scale grid-connected 
solar photovoltaic (PV) system development in Qinghai Province. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The 14th Session of the Standing Committee of the 10th National People’s Congress in 
February of 2005 enacted the Renewable Energy Law of the PRC, which provides a feed-in 
tariff  for  some  renewable  technologies,  specifies  grid-feed  in  requirements  and  standard 
procedures, and establishes incentives and supervisory measures for promoting renewable 
energy  development.  Both  the  11th  Five-Year  Plan  for  National  Economic  and  Social 
Development and the 11th Five-Year Plan for Energy Development encourage the diffusion of 
renewable energy and increasing its share in the total primary energy mix. In 2007, the National 
Development and Reform Commission issued the Medium and Long-Term Development Plan 
for Renewable Energy in the PRC, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy to 
10%  by  2010,  and  to  15%  by  2020.  In  November  2009,  the  State  Council  of  the  PRC 
announced that it planned to reduce carbon dioxide emissions per unit of gross domestic 
product by 40%–45% by 2020 compared with 2005 levels.  
 
3.   Increasing the share of renewable energy to attain the targeted energy mix by 2020 will 
also reduce carbon dioxide emissions. The share of renewable energy of the total primary 
energy mix has increased steadily, from 7% in 2005 to 9% in 2009, and is likely to reach the 
target of 10% in 2010. However, the growth of all renewable energy sources has not been 
uniform. While wind power increased from 1.3 gigawatts (GW) in 2005 to 25 GW by 2009, solar 
power has grown more slowly2 because of its high unit cost of power generation.   
 
4.  Creating a domestic market for solar PV to attain the 20 GW national target by 2020 
remains a challenge. The PRC has great potential for solar energy, with more than 5,000 
megajoules per square meter (MJ/m2) of annual solar radiation and more than 2,000 hours’ 
average sunshine in two-thirds of the country. Solar cell production in the PRC has been 
growing rapidly since 2004 and reached 4,100 megawatts (MW) in 2009, making it the largest 
producer of solar cell in the world. However, the installed capacity of solar PV is still only 1.5% 
of the 20 GW target by 2020. Because the domestic solar PV market is small, more than 98%, 
or 4,011 MW, of solar cell production in the PRC is exported to Europe, Japan, and the United 
States.3 But the domestic market for solar PV is expected to grow with government support. The 
government launched the first concession program for a 10 MW class grid-connected solar PV 
system in Dunghuang, Gansu Province, in 2009, and initiated the nationwide grid-connected

solar PV concession program with 280 MW total installed capacity4 in 2010. The government 
also launched the “Golden Sun” program5 in 2009, providing subsidies for the capital investment 
costs of solar PV power plant construction, including grid-connected installation to accelerate 
commercial-based solar PV development. Since 2009, the offtake tariff of solar PV power 
generation has declined due to a competitive concession bidding program.6 The government 
estimates the generation cost of solar PV will be reduced by 8% per annum with domestic 
market growth, and will achieve grid parity by 2020.7  
 
 5.  Developing a stable grid-connected renewable energy system is another huge challenge 
in the PRC. Only 72% of total wind capacity is connected to the grid8 due to variations in power 
output because of the intermittent nature of wind. This output variation could decrease the 
accuracy of load forecast, affect grid dispatching and operation, and have a negative impact on 
the quality of the electricity supply and on grid stability. Solar energy, which has similarly 
fluctuating natural cycles over a short time scale, will also face output variation problems as the 
share of solar energy fed into the grid increases. Controlling power output variation remains 
imperative for large-scale grid-connected solar PV.    
 
6.  Qinghai Province, which is located in the northeastern part of the Qinghai–Xizang9 
plateau in western PRC, has abundant mineral and natural resources, while its gross regional 
domestic product (GRDP) is the second lowest of all the provinces in the PRC.10 To enhance 
economic development by utilizing these resources in an environmentally sustainable manner, 
the Qinghai provincial government has set a development agenda for promoting solar energy, 
which would supply clean electricity to the load center in the eastern part of the PRC, and for 
developing a solar PV-related supply-chain industry, utilizing more than 20 GW of solar power 
resource potential11 and the rich silica resources12 in the province.  
 
7.     Qinghai Province launched a large-scale grid-connected solar PV development program 
in 2009. However, limited access to advanced technology solutions to control output variation,

lack of personnel experience in grid-connected solar PV system design, and limited incentives 
to expand large-scale solar PV plant investment, have slowed development of solar power. The 
proposed TA aims to increase the capacity of grid-connected solar PV system development in 
Qinghai Province, by (i) introducing advanced technologies to lower barriers for development; 
(ii) enhancing local capacity in planning, design, construction, supply chain, and operation and 
maintenance (O&M); (iii) improving the design of 10 MW class grid-connected solar PV pilot 
plants; and (iv) improving provincial government policy for solar PV development in Qinghai 
Province.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The impact of the TA will be accelerated deployment of grid-connected solar PV plants 
in Qinghai Province. The outcome of the TA will be lowered capacity barriers in the planning, 
design, construction, and O&M of grid-connected solar PV development in Qinghai Province. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The key outputs of the TA include:  
(i)  Holding seminars to introduce advanced technology for grid-connected solar PV 
systems;  and  introducing  internationally  advanced  power  conditioner 
technologies,  including  a  master  control  and  monitoring  (MCM)  system  for 
controlling power output variation of the 10 MW class grid-connected solar PV.  
(ii)  Preparing  a  technical  guidance  note  to  strengthen  capacity  in  the  planning, 
design, construction, and O&M of a grid-connected solar PV system; assessing 
the capacity of potential resources, planning, system design, construction, O&M, 
and supply chain; and conducting capacity development training.  
(iii)  Improving the design of a pilot grid-connected solar PV plant. Reviewing the 
design of the pilot 10 MW class grid-connected solar PV system in terms of its 
technical and financial feasibility.  
(iv)  Preparing  a  policy  note,  including  key  findings  and  recommendations;  and 
organizing a workshop to disseminate information about grid-connected solar PV 
system development to provinces with large-scale grid-connected PV potential.  
 
10.   The main assumptions are (i) maintained government priorities and preferential tariffs 
for grid-connected solar PV development, and (ii) the active participation of relevant counterpart 
staff in capacity development tasks. The main risks are (i) low offtake electricity tariffs, which 
undermine sustainable investment in grid-connected solar PV development; and (ii) that TA 
recommendation  will  not  be  agreed  to  and  endorsed  by  the  executing  and  implementing 
agencies. There are no issues and risks associated with the social and environmental safeguard 
aspects. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA will cost $840,000 equivalent, of which $500,000 will be financed by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) and $200,000 will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  the  Multi-Donor  Clean  Energy  Fund13 under  the  Clean  Energy  Financing 
                                                 
13 Contributors: the governments of Australia, Norway, Spain, and Sweden.

4   
Partnership Facility, and administered by ADB on a front-load basis14. The government will 
finance  the  remaining  $140,000  equivalent  for  in-kind  provision  of  office  accommodation, 
counterpart staff, and a steering committee of the TA. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed 
in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time 
to time). Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  The TA will be implemented over 14 months, from January 2011 to February 2012. The 
consultants will submit the following reports in English and Chinese: (i) an inception report to be 
submitted  within  4  weeks  after  mobilization,  (ii)  a  midterm  report  to  be  submitted  within 
7 months after mobilization, (iii) a draft final report to be submitted within 12 months after 
mobilization, and (iv) a final report to be submitted within 1 month after receipt of comments 
from ADB and the government.  
 
13.  The executing agency will be the Qinghai Provincial Financial Bureau. The implementing 
agency will be Qinghai Brightness Engineering.15 The executing and implementing agencies will 
provide support to the consultants, including (i) adequately heated office space (with basic 
furniture,  an  international  telephone  line,  and  internet  access);  (ii)  bilingual  counterpart 
personnel available to work full time, if required; (iii) assistance with accommodations and with 
visas and other permits required by the consultants; and (iv) access to all necessary data, 
including documents, reports, accounts, drawings, and maps.  
 
14.  The implementation of the TA requires a wide range of data and assistance across 
departments of the Qinghai provincial government. A steering committee, to be chaired by the 
executing  agency,  consisting  of  members  from  the  Provincial  Development  and  Reform 
Committee, the Provincial Science and Technology Bureau, the Provincial Economy Committee, 
the Provincial Meteorological Bureau, the Haixi prefecture government, and the State Grid 
Company of Qinghai, will be formed to coordinate implementation of the TA.  
 
15.  The TA will require 16 person-months of international and 16 person-months of national 
consulting services. International experts will include (i) a solar PV planner (team leader), (ii) a 
solar PV engineer, (iii) a solar PV system designer, (iv) a solar PV supply-chain specialist, (v) a 
transmission engineer, and (vi) a financial analyst. National experts will include (i) a solar PV 
planner (deputy team leader), (ii) a solar PV engineer, (iii) a solar PV system designer, (iv) a 
solar PV supply chain specialist, (v) a transmission engineer, and (vi) a financial analyst. ADB 
will recruit the consulting firm (including international and national consultants) in accordance 
with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) through a 
quality- and cost-based selection method (with quality–cost ratio of 80:20), following submission 
of simplified technical proposals. ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time 
to  time)  will  be  followed  to  procure  equipment  under  the  TA.  Equipment  will  be  used  by 
consultants  during  TA  implementation  and  handed  over  to  the  executing  agency  upon 
completion. The terms of reference are in Appendix 3.  
 
16.  The TA will be monitored based on (i) consultants’ progress reports, and (ii) ADB’s TA 
review missions. During TA implementation, seminars and capacity development training will be

IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 to be 
financed  on  grant  basis  by  the  Multi-Donor  Clean  Energy  Fund  under  the  Clean  Energy 
Financing Partnership Facility, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent 
of  $500,000  on  a  grant  basis,  to  the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for 
Renewable Energy Development in Qinghai, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented over 14 months. The TA will require 
the services of 16 person-months of international and 16 person-months of national consultants.  
 
2.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  recruit  the  consulting  firm  (including 
international  and  national  consultants)  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) through a quality- and cost-based selection 
method to provide the services for implementation, management, and progress monitoring of 
the TA.  
 
A.  International Consultants  
 
3.  Solar Photovoltaic (PV) Planner (Team Leader) (international, 4 person-months). The 
expert should have a postgraduate degree in engineering or a related field, and at least 15 
years of experience in solar PV development, preferably in planning a 10 MW class grid-
connected solar PV system. The expert will   
(i)  demonstrate  assessment  tools  to  estimate  solar  radiation,  including  cloud 
prediction; draw sun path diagrams; and determine tilt and azimuth angles of

(ii)  demonstrate simulation tools to evaluate various options and to determine the

economic feasibility;   
(iii)  prepare recommendations for development planning, funding, and investment 
incentives for solar PV development in Qinghai Province; 
(iv)  conduct  a  comprehensive  pre-feasibility  assessment  of  the  priority  solar  PV 
system;  
(v)  prepare brief technical guidance notes and a capacity enhancement module, and 
conduct  capacity  development  training  for  relevant  counterpart  staff,  in 
consultation with the implementing agency; and  
(vi)  prepare a policy note, including key findings and recommendations on the basis 
of activities conducted under the TA, and organize workshops with potential

systems in Qinghai, and a capacity assessment of the implementing agency on 
(a) solar radiation estimation and cloud prediction, including local meteorological 
data  management,  analysis,  and  resource  forecasting;  and  (b) site  analysis, 
including sun path assessment and tilt and azimuth angles of solar array, to 
identify the core capacity needed for the development of a 10 MW class grid-
connected solar PV system; 
(ii)  conduct  a  capacity  assessment  of  the  implementing  agency  on  (a)  grid-
connected solar PV system configuration design, including solar module, power 
conditioner, and monitoring systems; (b) grid-connected solar PV plant design 
and construction; and (c) operation and maintenance (O&M) of a grid-connected

Appendix 3  11 
solar PV system, to identify the core capacity needed for the development of a 
10 MW class grid-connected solar PV system; 
(iii)  develop  benchmark  standards  and  criteria  for  selection  of  priority  PV  solar 
investment  projects,  evaluate  priority  investment  projects,  and  undertake  a 
comprehensive pre-feasibility assessment of the priority solar PV system;  
(iv)  coordinate  with  the  team  leader  to  prepare  technical  guidance  notes  and  a 
capacity enhancement module, and to conduct capacity development training for 
relevant counterpart staff, in consultation with the implementing agency; and  
(v)  coordinate with the team leader to prepare a policy note, including key findings 
and recommendations based on activities under the TA. 
 
5.  Solar PV System Designer (international, 4 person-months). The expert should have a 
postgraduate degree in engineering or a related field, and at least 10 years of experience in 
solar PV system design, preferably in the planning and design of a 10 MW class grid-connected 
solar PV system. The expert will  
(i)  introduce internationally advanced power conditioner technologies for the 10 MW 
class grid-connected solar PV system, and propose locally appropriate power 
conditioner technologies in terms of capacity, durability, cost, and performance;  
(ii)  introduce  internationally  advanced  technology  for  the  Master  Control  and 
Monitoring (MCM) system for operating and monitoring the 10 MW class grid-
connected solar PV system, and propose locally appropriate MCM system design 
in terms of reliability, efficiency, and cost;  
(iii)  review the detailed design of the pilot 10 MW class grid-connected solar PV 
system, and provide technical guidance, including (a) resource forecasting and 
site selection; (b) system configuration design; (c) applied inverter technology, 
including a Maximum Power Point Tracking control design; (d) applied power 
conditioner  technology;  (e)  applied  MCM  system  design;  and  (f)  cost 
effectiveness and efficiency;  
(iv)  coordinate  with  the  team  leader  to  prepare  technical  guidance  notes  and  a 
capacity enhancement module, and to conduct capacity development training for 
relevant counterpart staff, in consultation with the implementing agency; and  
(v)  coordinate with the team leader to prepare a policy note, including key findings 
and recommendations based on activities under the TA. 
 
6.  Solar PV Supply-Chain Specialist (international, 2 person-months). The expert should 
have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  engineering  or  a  related  field,  and  at  least  10  years  of 
experience in solar PV supply-chain development. The expert will  
(i)  assess the capacity and quality of the solar PV supply chain, including silicon 
solar wafer and solar cell production;  
(ii)  provide technical guidance to develop a feasible solar PV supply chain for a 10 
MW class grid-connected solar PV system in Qinghai Province;  
(iii)  coordinate  with  the  team  leader  to  prepare  technical  guidance  notes  and  a 
capacity enhancement module, and to conduct capacity development training for 
relevant counterpart staff, in consultation with the implementing agency; and  
(iv)  coordinate with the team leader to prepare a policy note, including key findings 
and recommendations based on activities under the TA.  
 
7.  Transmission Engineer (international, 2 person-months). The expert should have a 
postgraduate degree in engineering or a related field, and at least 10 years of experience in grid 
connection and protection, preferably for a 10 MW class grid-connected solar PV system. The 
expert will

12  Appendix 3 
 
(i)  introduce  international  best  practices  for  grid  protection  design  and  system 
configuration for a 10 MW class grid-connected solar PV system;  
(ii)  assist the implementing agency with liaising and discussing grid codes with grid 
operators, and with identifying the required grid protection system design;  
(iii)  review the detailed design of the pilot 10 MW class grid-connected solar PV 
system, and provide technical guidance on grid protection system configuration 
and design;  
(iv)  coordinate  with  the  team  leader  to  prepare  technical  guidance  notes  and  a 
capacity enhancement module, and to conduct capacity development training for 
relevant counterpart staff, in consultation with the implementing agency; and  
(v)  coordinate with the team leader to prepare a policy note, including key findings 
and recommendations based on the activities under the TA.  
 
8.  Financial  Analyst  (international,  1  person-month).  The  expert  should  have  a 
postgraduate degree in economics or a related field, and at least 10 years of experience in 
energy sector assessment and analysis, preferably in analytical work on renewable energy 
development. The expert will  
(i)  conduct a financial analysis of the pilot 10 MW class grid-connected solar PV 
system, including a pre-feasibility assessment for a priority solar PV system, 
incorporating a cost effectiveness and efficiency assessment, commercial and 
resource risk assessment, and lifecycle analysis;  
(ii)  identify an appropriate offtake electricity tariff, including affordability, and risk 
mitigation measures for the pilot 10 MW class grid-connected solar PV system, 
and assess financing needs and types of financing to lower cost barriers of the 
pilot 10 MW class grid-connected solar PV system;  
(iii)  review a provincial development plan for renewable energy, focusing on solar PV, 
and identify performance gaps, challenges, and opportunities; and prepare a 
policy  note  on  development  planning,  funding,  and  investment  incentives  to 
develop renewable energies, focusing on solar PV in Qinghai Province; and  
(iv)  coordinate with the team leader to prepare a policy note, including key findings 
and recommendations based on activities under the TA.  
 
B.     National Consultants 
 
9.  The national consultants will comprise  (i) a deputy team leader and solar PV planner 
(4 person-months), (ii) a solar PV engineer (3 person-months), (iii) a solar PV system designer 
(4 person-months), (iv) a solar PV supply-chain specialist (2 person-months), (v) a transmission 
engineer (2 person-months), and (vi) a financial analyst (1 person-month). They will work with 
the corresponding international consultants. They will also assist the international consultants in 
reviewing relevant reports, data, policies, and regulations, and will translate relevant documents 
into English.   
 
C.  Reports 
 
10.  The  consultant  shall  submit  the  following  reports  to  ADB  (in  English)  and  to  the 
executing and implementing agencies (in Chinese): 
(i)  Inception  report. It will be submitted within 4 weeks after commencement of 
services.  The  report  includes  a  detailed  work  program  plus  any  major 
inconsistencies in the terms of reference, staffing problems, or deficiencies in the 
implementing agency’s assistance.

Appendix 3  13 
(ii)  Interim  report. It will be submitted within 7 months after commencement of 
services.  The  report  includes  a preliminary  result  of  activities,  updated  work 
program, and any issues and concerns. 
  
(iii)  Draft final report. It will be submitted within 12 months after commencement of 
services. Upon submission of the draft final report, a final workshop will be held, 
attended by relevant stakeholders, to get feedback on the report. 
 
(iv)  Final report. It will be submitted within 1 month after receipt of comments from 
ADB and the government on the draft final report. The final report shall take into 
consideration  the  comments  of  ADB  and  the  executing  and  implementing 
agencies. A summary report, of a maximum of 10 pages, should be included in 
the final report.
